election_record.label: Massachusetts 1814 Lieutenant Governor

overview.note: There was considerable controversy over whether those citizens living on plantations in what is now the state of Maine should be allowed to vote in state elections. They did not pay taxes and many thought they should thus not be allowed to vote. Beginning in 1814, in many of the plantations, the votes were cast and counted and included separately in the Original Election Returns, with their totals not included among the aggregate state totals.

sub_unit.name: Alford
sub_unit.note: The votes from Alford were rejected.

sub_unit.name: Becket
sub_unit.note: William Gray received 1 vote as Hon. Gray.

sub_unit.name: Freetown
sub_unit.note: "Rejected for informality." Original Election Returns.

sub_unit.name: Westport
sub_unit.note: "Returned too late." Original Election Returns.

sub_unit.name: Thompsons Pond
sub_unit.note: Thompsons Pond was a plantation whose votes were counted and listed in the Original Election Returns but which were not included in the aggregate state totals.

sub_unit.note: "No return." Original Election Returns.

Hodgkin, Douglas I., ed. Records of Lewiston, Maine. Vol. I. Rockport, ME: Picton Press, 2001. 110.
Metcalf, John G. Annals of the Town of Mendon, from 1659 to 1880. Providence: E. L. Freeman, 1880. 492.
Turner, Hollis. The History of Peru, in the County of Oxford and State of Maine, from 1789 to 1911. Augusta, ME: Press of the Maine Farmer, 1911. 11.
